The cards in a stack of $2n$ cards are numbered consecutively from 1 through $2n$ from top to bottom. The top $n$ cards are removed, kept in order, and form pile $A.$ The remaining cards form pile $B.$ The cards are then restacked by taking cards alternately from the tops of pile $B$ and $A,$ respectively. In this process, card number $(n+1)$ becomes the bottom card of the new stack, card number 1 is on top of this card, and so on, until piles $A$ and $B$ are exhausted. If, after the restacking process, at least one card from each pile occupies the same position that it occupied in the original stack, the stack is named magical. For example, eight cards form a magical stack because cards number 3 and number 6 retain their original positions. Find the number of cards in the magical stack in which card number 131 retains its original position.
inference:
Let the number of cards in the stack be $2n$.
The card numbered 131 retains its original position.
This means the card numbered 131 is in position 131 in the original stack.
After the first step, pile A has cards 1 to n, and pile B has cards n+1 to 2n.
Let the card numbered k be in position i in the original stack.
After the restacking process, the card numbered k is in position $2i-1$ if $i \le n$, and $2i-1$ if $i \ge n+1$.
If card k is in position 131 in the original stack, it is in the $2i-1$ position in the restacking.
We have $2i-1=131$. This gives $2i = 132$, so $i = 66$.
Since $1 \le i \le 2n$, we have $1 \le 66 \le 2n$. This means $n \ge 33$.
Since card 131 is in position 131, it is in position $2 \times 66 - 1 = 131$ in the restacked stack.
If $i \le n$, then the card in position $i$ is in position $2i-1$ in the restacked stack.
If $i \ge n+1$, then the card in position $i$ is in position $2(i - n) - 1$ in the restacked stack.
If $i=66$, the position is $131$, which is $2i - 1 = 2(66) - 1 = 131$.
The card is in position 131 in the original stack.
If $k = 1$, position in original = 1, position after restack = 1.
If $k = n+1$, position in original = $n+1$, position after restack = $2(n+1-n) - 1 = 1$.
If $k = 2n$, position in original = $2n$, position after restack = $2(2n-n) - 1 = 2n-1$.
In general, if $k$ is in position $i$ in original, it is in position $i$ in new stack if $i=131$.
In the original stack, card 131 is at position 131.
After restacking, we want 131 to be in position 131.
The position of 131 in the restacked stack is $2i - 1 = 131$, which means $i = 66$.
For the card in position 131 to be in the same position, $i = 66$.
Then $1 \le 66 \le n$.
Card 131 is in the $i$-th position, and $2i - 1 = 131$, so $i = 66$.
Thus $2n \ge 131$.
We have $2n = 131$. $2n = 132$. So $n = 66$.
The card in position 131 in the original stack remains in position 131 in the restacked stack.
Final Answer: $\boxed{132}$
ground_truth: Since a card from B is placed on the bottom of the new stack, notice that cards from pile B will be marked as an even number in the new pile, while cards from pile A will be marked as odd in the new pile. Since 131 is odd and retains its original position in the stack, it must be in pile A. Also to retain its original position, exactly $131 - 1 = 130$ numbers must be in front of it. There are $\frac{130}{2} = 65$ cards from each of piles A, B in front of card 131. This suggests that $n = 131 + 65 = 196$; the total number of cards is $196 \cdot 2 = \boxed{392}$.
